newsitem.title: UK: "Pre-millenium bug" could hit software in 99 - FT.
newsitem.headline: "Pre-millenium bug" could hit software in 99 - FT.

text.p: Computer experts struggling to cope with the "millenium bug" in older software have discovered a new problem which could halt many systems in two years, the Financial Times said on Tuesday.
The newspaper said that programmers in the 1970s had entered the date September 9, 1999 (09/09/99 or 999999) to denote the end of a project or set of records.
The report said the code was devised to ensure records were processed in the right order. The first file was numbered 000000.
It said that as September 9, 1999 approached, many of the end-dates would be activated and bring programs to a premature halt.
The millenium bug stems from computer systems using two digits to show the year, which programmers originally used to save scarce processing capacity.
At the turn of the century, many computers will show 00 for the year and interpret it as 1900, potentially causing havoc. Companies are now racing to reprogam old software.
